Award.AwardTitle: An experimental test of the developmental stress hypothesis - fitness consequences of early versus late contaminant exposure
Award.AbstractNarration: Biologists predict that stress early in life should have a larger effect on organisms than the same stress experienced later in life. This theory is called the developmental stress hypothesis and if correct means that early stress experiences may have long last effects that impact an individual fitness by altering cues that are used by animals to assess each other as mates and/or competitors. If this hypothesis is correct then may taking into account environmental stressors it is possible to design more effective preservation and conservation actions as we know the mechanisms for how and why certain individuals will mate with each other and produce offspring that survive. This project will test the developmental stress hypothesis by examining physiological, immunological, developmental, and behavioral consequences of exposure to low levels of mercury in a well-studied bird?the zebra finch. Mercury is a global toxin but we know little about how small non-lethal amounts of mercury harm the body. Mercury contamination has been described by the current Federal administration as the "most important global chemical issue facing us today", so increasing our understanding of the impact on wildlife of this pernicious and mobile toxin will have important implications for national and international efforts to regulate mercury pollution. Graduate and undergraduate students participating in this project will indicate whether early life exposure to mercury is more damaging than later exposure to the same small amount of mercury. Pilot data indicate that the immune system will be suppressed, brain functions impaired, and breeding severely depressed; and that these effects will be most notable in the case of early-life exposure to mercury. This could change our perception of what a "safe" level of mercury is. As the zebra finch brain is a model for understanding human speech learning this project will also give insight as to how mercury affects human health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We had two overarching goals for this project. The first was to investigate further the effects of small amounts of dietary mercury on a bird that is commonly used as a model (reference) system in biology. The second goal was to explore the prediction that stress (experienced by consuming small amounts of mercury) early during life would have more of an impact on the birds than experiencing the same stress later in life.

 

The first goal is important because the amount of environmental mercury is increasing globally and increasing quite dramatically in specific localities. We know rather little about how exposure to moderate and low amounts of mercury affects the body, though it is clear that exposure to high amounts of mercury is toxic and leads to neurological problems and even death. By exposing zebra finches to the concentrations of mercury that we have observed in prey items at contaminated environmental sites and would commonly be reported in a tuna-fish sandwich (for human consumption), we have documented substantial, sub-lethal effects on birds. From cellular measures of stress, immune functioning, and physiology, through to behavior, spatial memory and, ultimately, their breeding performance, we have shown that exposure to these levels of mercury significantly impairs zebra finches. The strength of some of these results was surprising. For example, this “tuna-fish-sandwich” level of exposure leads to the birds producing approximately half as many viable offspring as they would if they weren’t exposed to mercury in their diet.

 

In exploring our second goal, we found that birds exposed to dietary mercury during only their first 60 days of life (from conception to those early days of hatching from an egg) has just as much effect on the birds than if they are exposed to mercury for their entire lives. Something crucial is happening during these early stages of growth and development that shifts these mercury-exposed birds onto another trajectory that they cannot recover from. Even if mercury is removed and the birds breed hundreds of days later, the early-life exposure to mercury still has its effects. Understanding this pattern is important as it tells us about the mechanisms by which birds are affected by a contaminant, such as mercury. This helps to plan for both conservation and public health action. Within this study we also found that much of the breeding depression (50% fewer baby birds) that results from this early-life exposure to mercury is manifest through the father rather than the mother. In particular, we have found that sperm counts and sperm functioning is severely depressed by exposure to dietary mercury. This was unexpected, as we thought females would be more sensitive to environmental stress.

 

Overall, this project has many applications to society. Our data has contributed to a large environmental settlement, with the goal of remediating a Northern Virginia watershed due to its historic contamination with mercury. Our findings that male fertility is largely affected by mercury points us to suggesting health warnings for fathers as much as we should issue public health warnings for pregnant mothers. In addition to interpreting the societal relevance of our scientific results, the structure of this project has allowed us to involve more than three-dozen students in long-term research projects. Most of these students were undergraduates and many from historically under-represented groups. Almost all of the students have presented their work at scientific meetings and more than a dozen have co-authored manuscripts related to this project. Of the students who have graduated from William & Mary, the vast majority have continued in science by entering graduate and professional schools and/or directly following careers in the health sciences, ecology and conservation, and teaching.
